I am prepared to cut my time from ten minutes to six minutes providing the remaining time is allocated equally between Deputies Sheehan and Lyons.
We are wasting time on this but if that proposal is acceptable to Deputies Sheehan and Lyons I will agree to it.
We have wasted five minutes already.
In accordance with the agreement Deputy Sheehan has three minutes.

I should like to congratulate the Taoiseach, and the Minister, on establishing the Committee on Small Businesses which consists of 16 Members of the three main parties in the House. The Members have a thorough knowledge of the problems that confront manufacturing industry. It is important that we have sound manufacturing industries run by people who have pride in their products and are competitive on the home and export markets. It is vital for manufacturing industries that all avenues are explored to capture home and export markets. Our industries should be in a position to compete with the best of opposition.

The need for small industries is greater now than at any time in the past. We should aim to promote the establishment of small businesses in all towns and villages. I dislike the policies that operated down the years with huge sums of money being allocated to foreigners who did not have any stake in the country. They came to reap the harvest of IDA grants but, having received the maximum amount, took the first plane back to Europe and forgot about the Irish people. It is well known that many enterprising Irish people who approached the IDA for State aid were refused and those with an address at Dusseldorf, Paris or Amsterdam were facilitated in every way. We must change that attitude and give our Irish entrepreneurs all the backing needed to get started.

We should concentrate on industries that derive raw materials from within the State. Why is it that we import £40 million worth of chipped potatoes when we have the finest climate in the world to grow potatoes? All our supermarkets sell frozen chips imported from Holland, Belgium and Canada. Our fishing industry could employ ten times more workers if properly operated. We are only skimming the surface as far as that industry is concerned. We must do something about smoking, marinating and canning. We are falling down in our commitment to the fishing industry. The Dutch and Norwegians are cashing in on that valuable industry while we stand idly by.
I must now call on Deputy Lyons.
I recommend the adoption of this report. It is a very good one. I congratulate our chairman, Deputy Yates, on its presentation and on having done an excellent job within a short time.
Deputy Lyons has three minutes.
It will be as well for me to get into top gear as quickly as I can bearing in mind the time available to me.

I suppose it is very bad to commence any debate with an element of criticism. My criticism is this, that the time allocated to such an important item as this report, as ordered by the Government, is to me, in one word, “deplorable”. The whole country at this time is turning its attention to the setting up of small industries as a means of redressing the massive unemployment obtaining. I compliment the people who sat for many hours in an endeavour to present this report.
I had a number of matters in the report underlined on which I had wanted to comment but time will not allow me. Under the heading of industrial costs the report had this to say:

Although State policy towards small industry is one of support there are contradictions including, on the one hand, a variety of support services through various agencies and, on the other, excessively high charges for such State provided commercial services as electricity.

MainHeading.P: Here I want to emphasise the costs of electricity in view of the debate we had earlier this week as yet unfinished. One of the most severe cost factors vis-à-vis our lack of competitiveness in small industries, indeed in large industries, has been highlighted in the report of this committee. I hope that when we resume the debate on the proposed costs of electricity to small industries the people who came into the House this morning, who waxed so eloquently, some of them for 35 minutes, will show, by marching up those steps, where they will go vis-à-vis small industries — rather than coming into this House taking up the time of Members who did not serve on that committee and who would have liked to contribute to this debate, pontificating, telling us what she or others could tell the relevant Minister of State. I condemn that attitude. I hope that the cost factor of electricity to small firms will be decided at the top of those steps by the people who are so concerned and who pontificated here this morning to us. I recommend, as does this report, that there should be a third tier of electricity charges for small industries. Import substitution is not being developed to the fullest possible extent.

I could continue for much longer. I must say that the legal aspect of small businesses constitutes a very serious problem for all firms but particularly for small ones which are labour-intensive and who may be unable to avail of the advantages of new technology.
I see I am running out of time already.

Speaker.P: The Deputy's time is expiring.

If there were some means available to me by which I could have this debate resumed I would avail of it. This arrangement is unacceptable to me, to members of the committee, to the electorate, that this debate should be knifed at this time, it being so important. Could I have the direction of the Chair?
There was an order made this morning to conclude this debate at 1.30 p.m., an order of the day.
How much have I remaining, a minute?
The Deputy is running out of time just now.
We were told this morning about the White Paper. This is such a disappointment I would need much more time to talk about it but I shall revert to it on another occasion.

MainHeading.P: I shall conclude by saying that my message to the Government for small industries, indeed for all industry, is to create an incentive, to encourage development, to ease taxation, providing the kind of funds which will stimulate our stifled economy, giving back our people the incentive to work and to create work.

Speaker.P: Deputy Yates, to conclude.

I regret also, like other Deputies, that there was not sufficient time to debate this report. As the time available to me is brief also, I should like to thank all members of the committee and of the House who spoke. We shall study the Official Report and take up any of the points they have made.
I should like to deal principally with the Minister's response to this report because I suppose in all respects, in relation to the implementation of this report, that is the most crucial.

MainHeading.P: The Minister made three or four points. First, he wanted to know what was a small firm, where is the line drawn? He said also that it was not altogether desirable that the Government should interfere in the management of private firms and said there would have to be strict cash limits, in terms of the implementation of industrial policy vis-à-vis State agencies, because we needed to create the right tax environment. The reason I did not go into any of this — which is basically a justification for our over 80 recommendations — is that I should have thought such a fundamental point would already have been taken on board by the Minister. Obviously his advisers are not at that level of understanding. Therefore, I should like now to justify it. The criterion for assessing what is a small firm is both quantitative and qualitative. There are assessments used both in Europe and in the United States with established criteria for so doing. For example, in the United States and EC it is 1-500; in AnCO it is 1-80; in the IDA 1-50, in the Small Firms Association it is 1-100 and so on. In relation to the qualitative criterion — which represents the level of output, of fixed assets and the level of employment — if there is any difficulty encountered in endeavouring to get statistics to justify a case for small firms, it is simply that the CSO are so out of date with regard to figures. But, just on the figures they do have and those I have from the IDA annual employment returns, one can prove, first of all, that 93 per cent of all small firms are indigenous and do not have the potential to repatriate profits. Therefore, any economic development there is purely for the good of this country. Second, between the years 1973 and 1980 employment doubled in small firms. The latest figures available to me say that, in 1982 — which figure subsequently increased — there were in excess of 99,750 people employed in small firms and small firms also represent 90 per cent of manufacturing firms. It needs to be pointed out also that 66 per cent of all exports belong to small firms.

Therefore, if one views the picture in terms of employment, wealth creation and balance of trade, there is no doubt that if one is not prepared to zone in and assist small firms, then it must be said that one's industrial policy is unsoundly based. Most people in the IDA will tell one that the level of mobility of industrial investment — take the high technology area of electronics — is extremely vulnerable, so that one must remember that as quickly as they came in they can pull out. There is the genuine fear felt — if one looks at the 500 per cent growth over the last ten years, the growth in the electronics — that the Scottish Development Agency, the Welsh Development Agency and the EC generally are now giving the types of incentives, in terms of grants, research and development and of corporation tax levels that Ireland was giving. This means that the incentives we have are now being copied. But we will not be able to keep pace with, say, Taiwan or Hong Kong vis-à-vis wages. Therefore, the future appears very vulnerable indeed. It must be remembered that, unless one builds up one's base of small firm development, if one depends on multinationals who may be operating in 22 countries simultaneously, then one could find that, within a period of months, there would be a rapid loss of investment to the detrimental effect of our economy.
The Minister spoke about interference in private companies.

Speaker.P: I would remind the Deputy that he has two minutes remaining.

I should say that what we were getting at there, first of all, was a pilot scheme to assess whether the IPC, the IMI or AnCO could do a better job purely on the basis of redeployment, as was said by Deputy F. Fahey and others. The point we are making here is that very few people scrutinise our existing State agencies. For example I did not hear the Minister this morning say that three years ago of the IDA personnel, 60 per cent were engaged in field work and 40 per cent in administration. Now the position is that those figures have been turned around, with 60 per cent in the centrally-heated offices.
Hear, hear.

That is the type of accountability about which I am speaking, and which we must have. Surely it is the primary role of politicians, in terms of policy, to monitor the State agencies that are advising the Minister and dictating the pace of policy. Of course, they are on the inter-face of industrial development and, of course, their opinion must be taken into account. Therefore, somebody must scrutinise them. If we say that the interaction of small firms vis-à-vis State agencies is not adequate, is not localised, does not constitute the best type of consultancy service, that is a sufficient criterion for a change of direction.

In those few words I have endeavoured to justify the need for a national policy for development of small firms in this sector. Of course, I take the Minister's point about the tax environment. The whole of our report on retail distribution says that that sector is being seen as a revenue earner, therefore, we say, get the State off their backs. This sector is different. There is here great potential for development, this is not a service sector, there is growth and employment potential here.

MainHeading.P: I thank the Minister for having acceded to our three requests in relation to the management committee, the three-yearly review and an early meeting with him. All of our input by way of aiding industrial policy is there and available and I am glad that he has acceded to that point. However, I should like the Minister to re-examine his position fundamentally in the context of the importance of small firms. I hope that this debate will prove to be the first step in the implementation of our 80 plus recommendations.
Question put and agreed to.

MainHeading.LHead: Second Report of the Select Committee on
MainHeading.Title: Second Report of the Select Committee on Crime, Lawlessness and Vandalism: Motion.

Speaker.P: I move:
That Dáil Éireann takes note of the Second Report of the Select Committee on Crime, Lawlessness and Vandalism: The role of officers of Customs and Excise in controlling the supply of illegal drugs.

We would be very foolish if we did not recognise that the problem of drug abuse in Ireland could become much worse if the necessary steps to prevent the import and distribution of illegal drugs are not taken in time. Those who make huge financial gains from trafficking in drugs will take every opportunity to increase the number of drug abusers. They do not discriminate between areas or social groups. We in this House must make it clear that we will take any measure and provide any resources necessary to defeat them.

MainHeading.P: We are examining the whole area of drug-related crime and the controls which are needed to prevent the import and distribution of illicit drugs. One of the areas which is considered to be vital is the control which operates to prevent illegal drugs from entering the country. This report relates to the important part played by customs officers. It highlights the need for an interdepartmental co-ordinated approach to the drugs problem. Our report, of necessity, has to deal with areas of health, justice and finance. We welcome the presence of the Minister for Finance here today.

I move this motion on behalf of the members of the Select Committee. We have been working for nearly a year now and have, to date, produced five reports and hope to present two further reports to the Dáil in the near future. Apart from the reports on neighbourhood watch and vagrancy, which have already been debated in this House, our other two reports deal with controls on the private security industry and a recent visit by myself and Deputies Mitchell and Wallace to Scotland Yard. I hope that we will have an opportunity in the near future to consider these two reports.

The members expressed serious concern about the problem of drugs and drug-related crime and a sub-committee was established to consider how best to tackle this topic. The sub-committee members were of the opinion that the question of controls by officers of Customs and Excise at the points of importation of illegal drugs could be considered as a separate topic and a report produced. Other areas will be the subject of a further report, for example: Garda surveillance on movement and dealing in drugs both within and outside the country and Garda community relations. Matters relating to the prosecution of drug offenders including the leglislation under which drug pushers and abusers are prosecuted. The question of imprisonment for drug dealers and abusers and the provision of treatment facilities and alternatives to imprisonment for drug addicts. The need for increasing awareness of the dangers of addiction. The committee had a meeting with representatives of the Irish Customs and Excise Union which had made a submission to us on the role that customs officers could play in the efforts to come to grips with illegal trafficking in drugs. We subsequently had a meeting with representatives of the Revenue Commissioners. Both of these meetings proved very useful and informative and afforded us an opportunity to see the problem from both perspectives and to form a balanced view of the existing difficulties.

We were anxious to have discussions with the Garda Commissioner or his representatives prior to finalising this report. The difficulties which we experienced with that request and which are outlined in our report, have, as I am sure the Members of this House are by now aware, been satisfactorily resolved. At a meeting with the Commissioner on 26 July, he agreed that he and his representatives will attend at meetings of the committee to discuss any of the matters which are under consideration. He will supply information on the practice and experience of the Garda Síochána but will not contribute to any policy recommendations. All members of the committee were very satisfied that this matter was resolved. At no stage did we want the Commissioner to get involved in policy matters — this is clearly a matter for the committee members. However, the Garda Síochána input into the committee's deliberations is essential if the committee is to have a balanced view of the various crime problems before making policy recommendations.

The Misuse of Drugs Bill, 1984, under consideration in the House and the committee decided to produce this report as quickly as possible in order that those recommendations requiring legislative effect could be implemented immediately. This Bill provided an ideal opportunity for making the changes which we thought were necessary. It also served to show the relevance of the committee system, if it is given an opportunity to develop and is taken seriously by the Government. I will deal in more detail with our recommendations at a later stage, but before doing so I wish to outline the position in relation to the problem of drug smuggling and the role of customs officers.

There was a great deal of confusion up to about a year or two ago as to the true extent of the drug problem in Ireland. On the one hand we were being advised by some authorities that the problem of drugs was very minor while, as politicians, we were being told an entirely different story. It was only when the Medico-Social Research Board undertook a survey of the misuse of drugs in one inner city area in Dublin in 1982 that a definite and reliable picture emerged in its report presented early in 1983.

That study confirmed what many persons close to the problem had been saying for a number of years, namely, that there is a serious problem of drug abuse in certain areas and that it is particularly prevalent in the 15-24 age group. This study found that the prevalence of heroin abuse in that age group was 10 per cent; but in those aged 15-19 it was 12 per cent and among females aged 15-19 it was 13 per cent. These figures were in some respects a great deal worse than the equivalent 1970 figures for New York black ghettos especially where females were concerned. This report confirmed that the findings of an earlier preliminary investigation, undertaken in July 1982, were not only realistic but, in fact, somewhat understated the scale of the problem.

While the smuggling of drugs is, in itself, a criminal offence, the abuse of drugs has unfortunately led to a considerable amount of other crime in the community. This arises where addicts resort to crime in order to obtain the finances necessary to feed their habit. The committee are convinced that this drug-related crime has been a big contributing factor in the rise in the level of recorded offences over the past few years. The Garda Commissioner's Report on Crime for 1983 shows a total of about 102,300 indictable offences as compared with 64,000 in 1979, giving an overall increase of 59 per cent. While there are varying estimates of the cost to feed an addict's habits, the committee was informed that it could cost anything between £100 and £300 for a heroin addict to feed his habit for one day. This is, however, probably on the higher side of the scale and probably does not represent the picture for all addicts. The need to finance this habit has led to a substantial rise in handbag snatching, larcenies and burglaries to which addicts resort in order to have the money to purchase illegal drugs.

The committee consider that greater efforts must be made to tackle this crime problem and its source and this report has that objective, namely, tackle the basis of the problem and by reducing the supply of drugs reduce the consequential drug-related criminal activity.

This country's first line of defence to the problem, namely, the barriers at the point of entry, must be geared to tackle the sources and prevent these commodities reaching the streets. Such action, assuming that it were to be successful, would reduce the demands for expensive follow-up activity as well as reducing the unquantifiable social cost of drug addiction in a young person.

We were informed by the Customs Union representatives that the present trend among drug smugglers is toward concealment on or in the body. These persons are referred to as “swallowers” or “stuffers” and have created, and continue to create, serious problems for the Customs and Excise service. We were advised that it can take from five to seven days for such concealed substances to pass through the body. There have been instances where it has taken considerably longer — in one case in fact up to 15 days. Members should be aware that there is considerable danger for the person concealing such substances in such a manner. Cases are recorded where death has occurred following the accidental release of drugs within the body when the package ruptured. This indicates the lengths to which some people will go to smuggle drugs and the obvious financial rewards to be gained by successfully bringing drugs through customs.

The customs service operate, in so far as their role in drug smuggling is concerned, under the provisions of the Customs Consolidation Act, 1876, and the Dangerous Drugs Act, 1934, which restrict the importation of certain controlled drugs, and customs officers are concerned with detecting offences involving the movement of such drugs across the customs frontier.

Ireland, being an island, should be better placed than other countries to combat the drug problem at source, namely, the original supply into the country. It is at these points of entry that the customs service have a major role to play, and we support any steps taken to improve the level of service available for this purpose. It must, at the same time, be realised that it is physically impossible to search every person coming into the country, and it is here that good intelligence work comes into operation. It is essential that there be good liaison between the Garda and the customs service, and this aspect of the fight against drugs cannot be over-emphasised. There may be a natural tendency for each organisation to maximise its own individual efforts to tackle the problem. This could result in immediate short-term gains, but not tackle the root of the problem. For example, if a person coming into the country is carrying a sizeable quantity of drugs, it may be more beneficial not to detain him at customs but rather by alerting the Garda to have him put under surveillance. This could result in having some of the people behind the deal arrested and charged with crimes relating to trafficking in illegal drugs.

During the course of a recent visit to Scotland Yard by Deputy Mitchell, Deputy Wallace and myself, we had discussions with senior police officers in the Central Drugs Intelligence Unit. We were advised that there is a Steering Committee consisting of representatives of the Home Office, the police and the customs service overseeing the efforts to tackle the drug problem. They consider that this level of co-operation is essential if the authorities are to have a real chance of making inroads on the illegal trafficking in drugs.

Within the customs service there are two grades of officers appointed to the outdoor service, namely, assistant officer — 383 persons — and officer — 312 persons — who are mainly concerned with the detection and prevention of smuggling at the ports, airports and along the land frontier.

The customs procedures for dealing with drug smuggling were discussed with the representatives of both the Customs Union and the Revenue Commissioners. Officers of Customs and Excise are responsible for efforts to combat drug smuggling at the point of import only, or its immediate vicinity, while the illicit supply or use of drugs in all other areas of the country is a matter for the Garda. There is a very close working relationship between the Garda and the customs officers, and this spirit of co-operation must be continued and every effort and opportunity should be made or utilised to build on this. The Revenue Commissioners, the customs officers and the Garda level of co-operation was quite striking, and also their co-operation with the committee was very welcome and heart warming.

The committee were informed that when a customs officer seizes a quantity of dangerous drugs from an arriving passenger/or crew member, it is the practice to contact the Garda Drugs Squad. The time lapse between detection of the drugs and the arrival of the Garda Drugs Squad results in a “limbo” period during which the offender, as far as Customs and Excise are concerned, is, technically at least, free to continue his or her journey. The Customs Union representatives contended that, quite apart from the often embarrassing situations which can arise during such periods, it is very wasteful of the valuable time of both the Garda Drugs Squad and their members to have this duplication built into the system.

While officers of Customs and Excise have statutory powers of arrest under the Customs (Consolidation) Act, 1876, there is an administrative prohibition by the Revenue Commissioners on the exercise of this power. It appears that this prohibition was introduced because of the low level of penalties prescribed in the 1876 Act. It is preferable to await the arrival of the Garda and have proceedings, if any, taken under the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1977. The committee considered this to be a major problem and one which should be remedied immediately.

The committee consider that immediate steps should be taken to enable officers of Customs and Excise to play a more effective part in the fight against the supply of illegal drugs, and we make recommendations in our report, which I will summarise now and elaborate on later. Our recommendations are that:— 1. The provisions of sections 23, 26, 27 (1) and (3), 28 and 29 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1977, should be extended to officers of Customs and Excise by way of amendments to Misuse of Drugs Bill, 1984; 2. A small customs drugs unit should be established within the customs service; 3. Once the provisions of the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1977, are extended to officers of Customs and Excise, they should be free to immediately arrest and charge a person found to be smuggling drugs at a point of entry to the country. However, in this regard it is essential to ensure continued close co-operation and liaison with the Garda Drugs Squad; 4. Adequate resources must be provided to the customs service to enable them to examine and search vehicles and persons at points of import or export; 5. Urgent attention must be given and guidelines issued in connection with the procedures to be followed where there is suspected concealment on or in the body by persons generally referred to as “stuffers” or “swallowers”.

I will now outline some of the reasoning behind these recommendations. The 1977 Act gives powers to the Garda to assist them in their efforts to tackle the drug problem but no mention is made of the customs service or of their requirements in this area. They are the first in line to tackle the supply problem, and they should have similar powers to those of the Garda if they are to have a realistic chance of trying to deal with the problems of drug smuggling. The committee consider that the following provisions in the Misuse of Drugs Act need to be extended to officers of Customs and Excise, namely, sections 23, 26, 27 (1) and (3), 28 and 29.

Section 23 of the 1977 Act provides specific powers for the Garda Síochána to search persons where a member with reasonable cause suspects that a person is illegally in possession of drugs. Officers of Customs and Excise do not have authority to search a person who has not landed from a ship or aircraft. This can be very important where an officer suspects the passing of drugs from an arriving passenger to a “meeter” or “greeter”, which we were advised is a common phenomenon. The extension of the provisions of section 23 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1977, to officers of Customs and Excise would overcome this difficulty.

Section 26 of the 1977 Act provides for the issuing of search warrants to a named member of the Garda Síochána where there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that a drug offence has been committed. A customs officer may not legally attend or assist, in his capacity as an officer of Customs and Excise, at a search under such a warrant. In order to do so, a second warrant, to be issued under the Customs Consolidation Act, 1876, would be required. This creates unnecessary duplication especially where the attendance of such an officer is necessary to assist in the search. It may, for instance, be advisable to have a customs officer present to examine import documentation. The provisions of section 26 should be extended to authorise customs officers to assist the Garda at searches where this is considered to be necessary or desirable.

The existing penalties for drug smuggling, where the offence is prosecuted by customs officers, are generally totally inadequate to meet present needs, and they should be the same as where similar offences are prosecuted by the Garda. The committee can see no good reason why widely differing penalties apply as between prosecutions brought by the customs and the Garda, two bodies having a responsibility for tackling the supply and movement of drugs. This anomaly, which would necessitate an extension of the provisions of section 27 (1) and 27 (3) of the 1977 Act, should be rectified immediately.

Courts have power, under section 28 of the 1977 Act, to remand persons convicted under certain sections of that Act, to obtain a report and in certain cases to arrange for the medical treatment or for the care of such persons. Again this provision only applies where the offence is prosecuted by the Garda and the committee feel that a similar provision should apply where customs officials prosecute drug offences. The committee are satisfied that the Revenue Commissioners are very conscious of their role in controlling the supply of illegal drugs and that the senior staff are fully committed to efforts to deal with this problem. However, it appears that no officers are assigned fulltime to this very important task. The committee consider the setting-up of a small drugs unit within the customs service as an immediate and essential requirement.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle John J. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Deputy has one minute left.

I have ten minutes at the end to reply. Could I take five minutes now and five at the end of the debate? Thank you. It is envisaged that this drugs unit would be small in number, perhaps three or four persons, who would be specially selected for membership of this unit. We are not in a position to definitively quantify the numbers or grading of the necessary staff. These are clearly matters for the Revenue Commissioners, as is the question as to whether this unit could be established through the redeployment of existing staff. While we are not a position to quantify the cost of this proposal, we consider that it would be relatively modest, even in present financial circumstances, and especially in comparison with the scale of the drug problem.

MainHeading.P: This unit would be responsible for providing the necessary back-up services for customs officers around the country. It would make arrangements for specialised training for all staff and for ensuring that there was an on-going programme of training and refresher training. The committee understand that about 70 per cent of all officers have received training in this area and acknowledge the input made to date. It appears from the huge increases in the level of drug seizures by customs officers that this training is having a significant impact on the effectiveness of the customs service. The committee are of the view that if more emphasis can be given to this aspect of the work of Customs and Excise further substantial improvements in the level of seizures may take place. The aim of this unit should be the eventual reduction in the supply of illegal drugs and any funds invested in such activities will reap substantial real savings in the near future.

The Customs drug unit should liaise closely with the Garda drugs squad and be in a position to exchange information which may prove invaluable in the apprehension of drug smugglers and/or their accomplices.

In 1981 the Revenue Commissioners introduced an American manufactured kit called the Nik Porta-pac testing kit for use at all customs posts to assist in the identification of drugs. All officers received a half day's instruction in the use of these kits, which are very easy to use and which have proved to be very reliable. Ireland was the first country in Europe to use these kits and since their introduction here they have been brought into use in the rest of Europe. Section 186 of the Customs Consolidation Act, 1876, authorises officers of Customs and Excise to arrest and charge persons suspected of customs offences. However, the Revenue Commissioners have issued a direction prohibiting the exercise of this power without their prior consent. The committee were advised this was done because the penalties which are prescribed in the 1876 Act and which would be applied in the event of a successful conviction, are very low in comparison with those set out in the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1977.

We are of the view that the penalties prescribed for customs offences related to drug smuggling should be increased to bring them into line with those in the 1977 Act and following this officers of Customs and Excise should have authority to use their powers of arrest.

If the customs service is to have a realistic chance of successfully tackling the drug smuggling problem then not alone must the necessary legislative changes be introduced but adequate resources must be provided.

The provision of sniffer dogs would considerably assist customs officers in detecting drugs. The members realise that there are obvious limitations to their use as, for instance, where drugs are enclosed in certain protective materials which make it impossible for dogs to detect the drugs. I understand that one dog is now being trained for this type of work. The committee consider that this training should proceed and that further dogs should be provided as soon as possible.

There is a need for the provision of adequate physical resources to enable the customs officers to effectively discharge their functions in the examination of vehicles and persons. The committee are not in a position to comment on the level of such resources but we are advised that they are not adequate. We have also been advised that there is a need for the provision of covered examination bays with pits, ramps and hoists to enable vehicles to be examined. The Revenue Commissioners should examine the level of such facilities and consider if an improvement is necessary.

It has been suggested that X-ray and other specialised equipment be made available to the customs service. While the committee favour the provision of any resources which may assist in the efforts to reduce the supply of illegal drugs, the members understand that there may be health and substantial financial problems in relation to certain x-ray equipment. However, these possibilities should be considered by the Revenue Commissioners as, indeed, should the feasibility of using mobile units.

We have had developments since the report and we are very glad to say that there have been a number of amendments in the House which brought the penalties for drug offences into line with those for offences prosecuted by the Garda, which empowered the courts to remand persons along the lines we requested earlier. The provisions in the 1977 Act relating to defence proceedings have been extended to Customs and Excise and it has been provided that an officer of Customs and Excise could be named on a search warrant issued by a member of the Garda Síochána. We are very happy that these steps have been taken and it can be seen that the purpose of the recommendations is to give the customs service the same legislative action as the Garda. One recommendation was not acted upon, however, under section 23.

Customs and Excise officers have an important part to play in the fight against the smuggling of illegal drugs. They are very keen to help and their record, both in seizures of drugs and in their co-operation with the Garda, is excellent. An indication of their success is the fact that in 1983 the customs service uncovered 427 kilograms of drugs out of a total of less than 550 kilograms seized by all agencies nationally.
We presented this report in a very constructive spirit and I trust that it will be accepted in that spirit. So far, it certainly has been.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: Could I begin by thanking my colleagues in the House, particularly Deputy Doyle, for giving me the opportunity of making a few comments on this report at this point in the debate. I am sure that I am at one with all Members of the House in thanking the committee and their chairman for the way in which they have done their work and particularly for the way in which this report focuses attention on the principal issues which have to be addressed here.

We are all of the same mind on this issue. The kind of discussion that, we will have on this report will I hope, identify the priorities so that we can use the resources that we have and deploy them to the best effect.

MainHeading.P: The prevention and detection of drug smuggling are the responsibility of the Revenue Commissioners and officers of the Customs and Excise at points of entry into the State have the job of exercising their normal, proper vigilance in order to detect such smuggling. We all appreciate that their task is a difficult one. Even minute quantities of drugs can have very high street values. Small quantities can easily be concealed on persons and in vehicles. Comprehensive checking of persons and vehicles at points of entry would seriously impede the movement of passengers and cargoes. Nevertheless, customs officers have to strike a balance between effective control and the needs of the legitimate travellers and traders. Drug smugglers, of course, are keenly aware of the difficulties in detecting drugs and are very quick to exploit opportunities and to invent new methods of concealment when the need arises.

In this country we do not receive significant importations direct from countries which are known generally to be source countries for controlled drugs — for example, Pakistan, Thailand, Lebanon, Syria, India and parts of South America. From that point of view, consignments of goods from those countries would first come under customs control in another country before delivery here. There is thus already the possibility of detection in that country in which they first come under customs control, which tends to be of assistance to us and to reduce the scale of a problem with which we would otherwise have to deal.

The report mentions the international information exchange co-operation which already exists between the customs services in many countries and to which this country contributes. I would also point out that the Garda have formalised communication procedures with other countries within the framework of Interpol. As Deputy Woods has already pointed out, customs officers maintain a very close liaison with the Garda Síochána in all matters relating to possible illegal importation of drugs. The affects of this co-operation here, both at national and international level, are more extensive than is perhaps realised. They have proved to be invaluable in the apprehension of smugglers and the interception of drugs.

I do not in any way wish to suggest, or have my remarks taken to mean, that the position cannot be improved. It is clear that we need to improve the situation as rapidly and as much as we can. The Revenue Commissioners in order to do that have taken a number of steps to which I shall refer shortly. All the measures currently deployed to detect smuggling are kept under review, including the deployment of customs staff. While we would obviously wish to cut off completely the importation of illegal drugs, realistically we must accept that we will probably never be in a position to bring that about, even with a very substantial increase in customs staff. The conclusion I draw from that is that we must concentrate in the most efficient manner possible those resources that we can make available.

The special task force set up by the Government to consider all aspects of the drugs problem recommended that the penalties in the Misuse of Drugs Acts and the Customs Acts be aligned. This has been done already in the Misuse of Drugs Acts, 1984. The task force recommended also the use of sniffer dogs, X-ray and other modern detector equipment. As Deputy Woods has said, a sniffer dog for the customs is undergoing training. A panel of prospective dog hunters has been established and the usefulness of this aspect of detection will be reviewed in the light of experience.

In regard to modern detector equipment, our customs have been using sucessfully the most modern equipment available. They are keeping abreast of developments in other countries and consideration will be given to the introduction of any worth while improvement that may be effected in the light of what might be its applicability here. In regard to X-ray equipment there are certain considerations that must be taken into account, for example, the health risks that might be involved in respect of the staff operating the equipment and, I am obliged to say, also the cost involves. The Revenue Commissioners are considering the possible effectiveness of other technical equipment. Specialised equipment is in operation already on an experimental basis for the checking of container traffic.

The Report has drawn attention to the lack of powers for customs officers in certain aspects of drug prevention and detection. The lack of powers to accompany gardaí in the search of premises, under warrant, has been remedied in the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1984.

A number of proposals by the Revenue Commissioners for legislation to confer additional powers on customs officers similar to those conferred on the Garda under the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1984, are being studied.

These proposals relate to powers of detention and search of persons, vehicles, vessels or aircraft suspected of being concerned in the illegal importation or exportation of controlled drugs and to the search of premises or lands and the examination of suspect books, records or other documents.

While there is no specific drugs squad within the customs service, the Customs Investigation Branch play a leading role in this area. They co-operate with local staff as required and with the Garda. Many of the larger seizures in this country in recent years resulted from combined action by local staff, investigation branch and the Garda. A higher officer and an officer attached to the investigation branch have direct responsibility for maintaining liaison with the Garda and with enforcement agencies in other countries and for the gathering and use of intelligence concerning dangerous drugs. These officers spend practically all of their official time on this work.
Special operations are mounted from time to time at import points to ensure more effective control of the smuggling of illicit drugs from known sensitive areas.

Customs officers have power to arrest and charge persons. Such action is usually done with the prior authority of the Revenue Commissioners, but a collector of customs and excise can authorise and arrest or if he cannot be contacted, a surveyor or higher officer may give permission.

The Report mentions the problem of obtaining valuation of drugs for the purposes of legal proceedings under section 186 of the Customs Consolidation Act, 1876. This problem has been overcome and the penalties in the Misuse of Drugs Acts, 1977 and 1984, which do not relate to value, now apply.

In regard to the physical resources to assist customs officers in the effective examination of vehicles I am informed that existing fixed facilities are adequate at most points of entry. Where special examination is deemed necessary and specialised facilities are required, goods and vehicles can be removed to places where such facilities are available.

The committee and the chairman just now concentrated on the problems of drugs swallowers and stuffers. This problem deserves a great deal of attention from a number of different points of view, for example, from the point of view of the illegal importation of drugs and also, as Deputy Woods said, from the point of view of the damage the people involved can do to themselves. It is a problem of which the Revenue Commissioners are keenly aware and I am glad that we have the committee's reflections to add to the work of the Commissioners.

Regarding the manpower resources that are available, some 400 customs officers of varying rank are employed in preventive controls at airports, ports and land frontier stations. These officials, as part of their duties, deal with smuggling by individuals as well as with the search of ships, aircraft and vehicles for contraband. They are trained in the identification and detection of drugs and they examine baggage and question selected passengers specifically as to possession of drugs, having regard in their selection to where the passengers originated and the transit points through which passage was made.
As part of normal control of imports, commercial cargoes are also physically examined on a selective basis by customs officials other than those specifically engaged on preventive duties.

I am very pleased that the committee have been able to give so much attention to this problem. We can say fairly that a number of the areas of concern raised by the committee have been the subject of action in the meantime and along the lines recommended by them.

I repeat that the work of the committee has been extremely useful. It has focused attention on the more pressing issues that need to be dealt with. That is something that properly is part of the work of committees of that kind. To the extent that in any of their future work the committee may wish to return to any of these problems, I assure them that there will be forthcoming from the Revenue Commissioners the same level of co-operation as we were happy to be able to give on this occasion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. V. Brady Mr. V. Brady
Speaker.P: This is a very timely debate on the very serious problem of drugs. The onus rests very much now on us as legislators to do something about that problem.

In the past couple of years there have been a number of notable seizures by customs and excise officers at various points of entry. Their continuing co-operation with the Garda is acknowledged by the Commissioner in the Garda report for 1983. However, it is not sufficient for the Commissioner to say that the co-operation is beneficial, because such a statement would appear to reduce to a low profile, if not eliminate, the roll of the customs officers. Co-operation between customs officers and the Garda is also very important because the role customs officers play in the fight against drug imports could be helped considerably by the presence of the Garda to facilitate a quick drugs seizure.

The work of the committee has been going on at a satisfactory level, but unless their recommendations are acknowledged by the Government and the Minister I am afraid the committee are wasting their time producing excellent reports of this kind. I am glad that the Minister for Finance confirmed that the views expressed in the report are acceptable to the Government. The matter of finance comes into this, but if the required action is to be taken and if it is successful hundreds of millions of pounds could be saved to the Exchequer which now is being lost in various ways because of the illegal importation of drugs.

MainHeading.P: The level of crime throughout the country, and in Dublin in particular, has increased to frightening proportions. There is evidence that a large percentage of crime is carried out purely because of the urgent need for cash to finance the purchase of drugs. There was a general feeling some years ago that breaking into chemists' shops provided the hard drugs necessary to sustain the habit, but during recent years this has been controlled to a great extent. However, the problem has increased and is growing worse daily. Successful raids have been carried out by the Garda to beat the drug smugglers, but drug smuggling is at an intolerably high level, and unless some positive action is taken not only to curb smuggling but to eliminate it I am afraid the country will lose the fight for law and order.

Unfortunately, our younger people are exposed to every possible risk. The sale of drugs has become a huge commercial business for the unscrupulous godfathers of the industry. A large number of them well known to the Garda, are living lives of luxury at the expense of the unfortunate ones caught up, perhaps through no fault of their own, through inexperience, in this terrible business.

Though the smuggling of drugs is in itself a serious problem, the abuse of drugs has led to a considerable amount of other crimes throughout the community. Addicts, apparently, must involve themselves in crime in order to finance their habit. The committee found that it costs anything between £100 and £300 to finance the daily drug needs of addicts. This has led to an enormous increase in crime, largely burglaries.

I hope the report of the committee will be a first step towards easing this awful problem. Customs and excise officers are in an ideal position to control imports and smuggling of drugs, but if they are to be successful a number of changes must be made. They must be given new powers and facilities and there must be provision for additional training for recruits. Under present law if an officer observes possible possession of drugs, valuable time is wasted while he makes contact with the Garda. During that time an offender may get away. This is very serious and it must be sorted out very soon.

Of travellers passing through our ports only about 20 per cent are called aside for examination, and very often those called aside are innocent travellers, perhaps carrying an additional bottle or some extra cigarettes. Our customs officials are very courteous and as far as I know it is very rare to find one of them discourteous to anybody. However, the hard fact remains that travellers can walk through our ports freely and they could be carrying quantities of drugs on their persons.

I have been told that for a good number of years the customs people have been expressing their concern at the lack of response from the Revenue Commissioners. Frequent representations have been made to the Revenue Commissioners indicating that the responsibility rests with them regarding the control of importation of illegal drugs, but this is very far down in their list of priorities. Unfortunately, hardly any part of the country is now unaffected in some way or another by drugs but of course the urban areas, the bigger cities particularly, are the worst affected. Dublin, with its huge population, has a very serious problem.

In recent times a number of deaths have occurred either directly or indirectly associated with drug abuse. Some commentators and medical people have indicated that many other deaths, from accidents on the roads or at home, have been caused indirectly by drug taking. Some parts of Dublin are worse than other parts. The inner city, as we all know, has a major drugs problem but suburban areas are also badly affected.

One of the most dreadful problems we have at the moment is the presence of pushers outside schools trying to persuade young people to take sweets containing drugs, some with very hard drugs. Those pushers are not particularly concerned whether their victims are old or young. I do not think the authorities are fully alive to this danger. The problem would not be so great, of course, if there was full control at the points of importation. Some months ago there was a heroin haul, worth £8 million, in Birmingham. At that time the Garda indicated that it was intended for Ireland. Though I do not wish to take away from the work of the Garda and the customs officers, I am quite sure that this haul would not have been detected coming through Irish ports. When one considers that this may have been just a normal transaction scheduled to come through in the normal way, through normal channels, it is frightening to think of the consequences for our community of that type of smuggling. Our present setup is highly undesirable. There is no proper control at the ports.

This report has been compiled in a very serious and concerned way. The committee heard many submissions from different groups all of whom are doing excellent work in their own way, but they are hampered particularly by the lack of proper legislation. I hope that in the short term the report will make it clear to all responsible, particularly the Government, that irrespective of cost the steps proposed in the report must be taken. No matter what the cost may be, in the final analysis it will benefit the community as a whole.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Doyle Mr. J. Doyle
Speaker.P: I am pleased to have this opportunity to contribute to the debate on a report dealing with the role customs officers play in controlling the supply of illegal drugs. Prevention is better than cure. It was with this maxim in mind that I and other members of the committee considered the role of the customs officers as fundamental in any effort to stop or reduce the supply of drugs. Their role in this matter should be emphasised. If customs officers can succeed in reducing the quantity of drugs being smuggled into this country then the subsequent cost of drug addiction will be significantly reduced.

MainHeading.P: There are about 600 customs officers placed at strategic points at airports and seaports. They are required to provide a service on a 24 hour basis. When one realises the traffic and number of people they have to contend with the number of officers seems small. Despite their numbers and the extent to which their role in preventing and detecting drug smuggling has been overlooked, these officers have been very successful in their seizures of illegal drugs. It is extremely difficult to detect drug smuggling and the extent to which smugglers can smuggle and hide drugs. The street value of even a small quantity of drugs is very high and the rewards compare favourably to the risks involved. There was a case of a young girl having heroin with a street value of £276,000 in the pocket of her jeans. She was caught but many others get through. When one considers the number of juggernauts and heavy vehicles coming through our ports everyday, not to mention private cars, the task seems impossible. I have heard that private cars have been deliberately dented and then filled with heroin and painted over.

Deputy Woods spoke about the new phenomenon of smuggling drugs by swallowing. This is a serious problem. I was glad to hear the Minister say he would provide facilities at points of import and export to deal with this matter.

In the annual report for 1983 the Garda Commissioner stated that many seizures of drugs were made by officers of the customs service at various points of entry to the State. Their co-operation is beneficial as almost all drugs abused here are brought into the country. In 1981 1,620 kilogrammes of cannabis out of a total of 1,735 kilogrammes seized was as a result of joint customs and Garda operations. If we can improve the efficiency of the customs services there will be a significant increase in the level of drug seizures at the point of import. This would lessen the problem and avoid the other serious consequences of drug smuggling.

There is no doubt but that society pays for drug addiction. This payment can be made in the form of handbag snatching, petty larcenies and burglaries. People have to pay for health care services through taxation. Drug related crime is committed to feed an addict's habit while the health services are called upon to treat the effects of drug addiction.

The chairman of the committee welcomed the changes in legislation which have been implemented in the Misuse of Drugs Bill, 1984. I do not propose to dwell on that aspect except to say that I was very pleased to see the speed with which the Minister for Health responded positively to the report by making amendments to that Bill.

At our meeting with representatives of the Customs and Excise Union they complained that the lack of personnel and training facilities hampered their efforts in preventing drug smuggling. They reminded us of the commitment given by the Minister for Finance in the 1983 Budget. I am glad the Minister listened to the debate and that he was gracious in his comments about the work of the committee. I was glad to hear that the Revenue Commissioners will give all necessary aid to the customs officers in their work.

Drug smuggling is a major issue. I understand very little has been done to date to establish a small drug unit in the customs service. That is essential. We are unanimous in the report that there should be a full time drug unit with trained staff. They should provide the necessary back up services for officers in the field and thus help to tackle the problem. I hope the Revenue Commissioners will consider the situation where customs officers cannot arrest and charge a person for drug offences. There is clear need for a change of policy in this regard and the introduction of comprehensive guidelines outlining a simplified but effective procedure for dealing with such cases. Customs and excise officers are responsible for combatting drug smuggling at the point of import only or in the immediate vicinity while the illicit supply or use of drugs in other areas is a matter for the gardaí. There is a close working relationship between the gardaí and the customs officers. That spirit of co-operation must be continued. Every effort should be made to build on this solid basis.

In the different committees of which I am a member we have from time to time received numerous deputations. I was most impressed with the deputation we received from the customs officers' association. They are most dedicated and conscientious in their efforts to eradicate the drug problem. There is a grave responsibility on the State to support in every possible way this excellent group of people in their efforts to curtail the drug problem which now affects so many parts of the country.
Debate adjourned.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Galway City Sewerage Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the present position regarding the proposed erection of a pump-house and outfall piping for Galway main drainage at South Park in Galway city; and whether he has now decided the scheme will include treatment of effluent prior to discharge.

As a result of representations made to me by local representatives and residents regarding this scheme I agreed that the corporation could have time to re-examine their original proposals without losing the capital for the scheme. A revised preliminary report which has been received from the local authority proposes that the pumping station be relocated on Mutton Island and that a causeway be built to service the station. The report does not contain a proposal to change the effluent treatment arrangement from that in the original design. The revised proposals are under examination in my Department.

The additional cost as a result of the relocation of the pumping station and the building of a causeway is estimated at £1.75 million. That factor must be carefully considered. The estimated cost of the pumping station at South Park is £2.85 million and the estimated cost of a pumping station located at Mutton Island is £4.6 million. Under this new proposal a number of additional points must be examined before it can be decided upon. The building of the causeway could interfere with the existing tidal flows and have implications for the shipping channel, or the causeway could be designed to minimise any adverse effect. Hydrographic and sediment transportation studies will be necessary and this will take six months or more. A foreshore licence will be required for the construction of the cause-way and the original mechanical and electrical plant which has been constructed may be of minimal use and could end up being totally unsuitable. I am sure the Deputy will understand that these are major questions that must be considered.

These discussions are on-going and a further meeting is expected to be held shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Publication of Opinion Polls.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will consider legislation governing the publication of opinion polls in the period before elections.

Would he not consider the introduction of some regulations, such as those that operate in continental countries, to regulate the publication of opinion polls in the period between the Dáil being dissolved and the holding of a general election or any other election?

If there is some professional advice available in that regard, I am not aware of it. While recognising the worth of opinion polls I would not envisage a situation in which they could not be resorted to by political parties during election periods because there is evidence to suggest, particularly in the course of the last couple of elections, that their publication could have some influence.
